title: (x) Marathon Fr(ID)ay - 12 of 13 - Koch Rivoli {Mike Freiman}
content: Rivoli Initials. I'm pretty sure I've seen it digitized, but will have to hunt.
author: mike_f

comments.content:
another one that's close is Locarno, specifically Locarno Italic...   
   
 [http://www.identifont.com/show?304](http://web.archive.org/web/20050528000331/http:/www.identifont.com/show?304)

I don't have Texts on Type in front of me, but I remember an article   
on American Knockoffs.   
Rivoli is the "American Knockoff" of Locarno?

No Stephen, not that one. I'm again working from the Solotype Catalog, which lists two Rivoli Initials. One of them is your RR tyepface, the other Jared's match except for something I'd missed earlier ï¿½ while all of the other characters are a perfect match, Rivoli Initials has a curved left upright on the 'U'.   
   
Harold Lohner has made a version he calls [Koch Rivoli](http://web.archive.org/web/20050528000331/http:/members.aol.com/fontner/frontpage.html) (see Revivals).

Yikes. Why did my text not wrap?   
   
Scrollsville man!

Following Harold Lohner's pointer to an original font name  
 of Zierbuchstaben, I discovered that Dieter Steffmann's  
 fonts (PC only) are back online (Hooray! says I) and he  
 offers a version called [Koch Antiqua Zierbuchstaben](http://web.archive.org/web/20050528000331/http:/moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/index.htm).   
   
Lohner states that Koch's Zierbuchstaben was designed  
 as a companion to Koch Antiqua and Steffman's font  
 incorporates Koch Antiqua's lower case.   
   
Unfortunately, Steffman's version is rougher and he seems  
 to have neglected the 'I'.   
   
So what do you think Jared? Does your image simply  
 incorporate an alternate 'U'?
